headline: Facebook’s Stock Plunge Shatters Faith in Tech Companies’ Invincibility
snippet: Roughly $120 billion in wealth was wiped out as Facebook shares fell 19 percent. It was among the largest one-day destruction a company has ever suffered.

headline: Germans Are Getting on Twitter. Is That a Good Thing?
snippet: The country is late to Twitter and Facebook — but it hasn’t learned from other countries’ mistakes.

headline: Facebook Starts Paying a Price for Scandals
snippet: The social network said that advertising and user growth slowed in the second quarter, and that efforts to improve privacy would stunt profits further. Its stock price tumbled.

headline: China Said to Quickly Withdraw Approval for New Facebook Venture
snippet: For a moment it seemed like the world’s biggest social network had established a beachhead in the world’s largest internet market. But only for a moment.

headline: Tech Companies Like Facebook and Twitter Are Drawing Lines. It’ll Be Messy.
snippet: Big tech companies are asking themselves where their responsibilities start and stop. Sorting that out will be complicated and may end up increasing their power.

headline: A Trusted Pill Turned Deadly. How Tylenol Made a Comeback.
snippet: How do companies regain public trust after something goes seriously wrong? We looked at how Tylenol responded after someone inexplicably spiked its pills with poison in the 1980s.

headline: How an Unsolved Mystery Changed the Way We Take Pills
snippet: The origins of tamper-resistant packaging — exasperating yet reassuring — lie in a deadly episode in 1982, when cyanide-laced Tylenol killed seven people.

headline: Prosecutors Are Said to Issue Subpoenas Over Pelvic-Mesh Surgery Financing
snippet: The subpoenas from federal prosecutors in Brooklyn suggest the authorities are intensifying an investigation into allegations of fraud against a network of doctors, lawyers and consultants.

headline: Watch How a Baby and Blueberries Debunk Myths About Chemicals
snippet: Do you pause when reading the ingredients on a label? How do you know what chemicals are safe? Johnson & Johnson is debunking common myths and curing our chemophobia — with babies and blueberries.

headline: Justice Dept. Investigating Claims That Drug Companies Funded Terrorism in Iraq
snippet: In a filing, AstraZeneca said the case was related to a suit that accused five companies of giving the Iraqi health ministry drugs and devices that were then sold to fund attacks.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Told to Pay $4.7 Billion in Baby Powder Lawsuit
snippet: Johnson & Johnson must pay damages to women who claimed that asbestos in talcum powder products caused them to develop ovarian cancer.

headline: Is Baby Powder Dangerous? Does Industry Even Care?
snippet: A historic ruling against Johnson & Johnson over its talcum powder products rests on uncertain science — but reveals a very real trust problem for such companies.

headline: F.D.A. Did Not Intervene to Curb Risky Fentanyl Prescriptions
snippet: Powerful cancer pain drugs were given to patients with other conditions who cannot tolerate them. A program to curb the practice was run by companies that sell the drugs.

headline: The Stealth Campaign to Kill Off Obamacare
snippet: How the countrys largest lobbyist for the pharmaceutical industry is using dark money to support an advocacy groups efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Merck Is Lowering Drug Prices. There’s a Catch.
snippet: The drugs singled out for discounts include the flagging hepatitis C treatment Zepatier and six drugs that have lost their patent protection.

headline: Ebola Outbreak in Congo Has Ended, W.H.O. Says
snippet: The outbreak, the first in which a new vaccine was quickly rolled out, was extinguished in less than three months, with 33 deaths.

headline: Alfred Alberts, Unsung Father of a Cholesterol Drug, Dies at 87
snippet: His discovery led to lovastatin, but he shunned the limelight — until he was a patient himself and doctors, learning who he was, treated him “like a rock star.”

headline: NYT: Today's Business With Natasha Singer
snippet: Jeff Sommer and Natasha Singer on Merck's $41 billion acquisition of Schering-Plough.

headline: Putin Is Running a Destructive Cybercrime Syndicate Out of Russia
snippet: Every day, cybercrooks inflict immense harm on real victims across our country and around the world. Will Trump protest?

headline: How the Trump Administration Is Browbeating Big Pharma on Drug Prices
snippet: Administration officials issued a blunt warning to the board of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, and announced a flurry of actions and plans to coincide with the meeting.

headline: Surprise Gift: Free Tuition for All N.Y.U. Medical Students
snippet: A plan will cover the $55,000 annual tuition for every current and future New York University School of Medicine student, regardless of financial need.

headline: Michael Cohen, Missouri, Trump: Your Friday Evening Briefing
snippet: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: For the First Time, a Female Ebola Survivor Infects Others
snippet: A Liberian woman recovered after tending to her dying brother, but infected her family a year later. Being pregnant may have reignited the virus in her.

headline: Starring in That Drug Commercial? An Actual Patient
snippet: Pharmaceutical ads have long featured healthy-looking actors or celebrity pitches. Now there’s an increased desire to use people who have taken the medications.

headline: Interviewing Elon Musk
snippet: For our Corner Office columnist, an hour with a deeply emotional Mr. Musk was not just another C.E.O. interview.

headline: Lasker Awards Given for Work in Genetics, Anesthesia and Promoting Women in Science
snippet: The coveted prize was awarded to a Scottish veterinarian, two scientists who championed an overlooked protein and a pioneering researcher who helped advance the careers of other women.

headline: Sloan Kettering Executive Turns Over Windfall Stake in Biotech Start-Up
snippet: With the cancer center’s corporate ties under scrutiny, the hospital told employees that no one should profit personally from representing MSK on outside boards.

headline: Ebola Attacked Congo Again. But Now Congo Seems to Be Winning
snippet: New cases are dropping sharply, vaccination is going well and schools are about to open. But it is too soon to declare victory, experts said.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Does Facebook Have Room for More Than One Founder?
snippet: The social network pays big bucks for start-ups. But founders seem uncomfortable with what happens afterward.

headline: Now in Sight: Success Against an Infection That Blinds
snippet: Following a 20-year campaign, trachoma has been eliminated as a public health menace in at least seven poor countries.

headline: Top Cancer Researcher Fails to Disclose Corporate Financial Ties in Major Research Journals
snippet: A senior official at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center has received millions of dollars in payments from companies that are involved in medical research.

headline: Health Secretary Defends Actions on Drug Prices
snippet: Alex Azar counters an editorial saying the administration has done “nothing good” to keep prices down.
